text:
What’s everyone’s take on Taleb? I’d sort of dismissed him as a bit of a dick whose books are overly long and anecdotal but this is without having actually read any of them

But based on <@U01B8031PM1>’s recent thread on A Man For All Markets (<https://betcode-org.slack.com/archives/C4H05KKMY/p1689500263793199|https://betcode-org.slack.com/archives/C4H05KKMY/p1689500263793199>), I am rereading that book and I see that Taleb wrote the foreword. The implicit endorsement by Thorp makes me wonder if I need to rethink my stance on Taleb

elements.text: Just finished and highly recommend for all quant gamblers:

text: He is a dick (usually comical) and you're right about his books being long (and quite repetitive) but have always found his way of thinking really sound and completely out of the mainstream.

text: Does he have a good track record?

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: Does he have a good track record?

text: If you're involved in financial markets definitely read the books. Can't say I've found him useful for our stuff but I haven't delved into his more mathematical approaches. I can't speak to his track record, but his critique on risk analysis is very convincing and comes with lots of evidence. A lot of his thought is a distillation of benoit mandelbrot on financial markets. His twitter is too personal for my liking.

elements.text: If you're involved in financial markets definitely read the books. Can't say I've found him useful for our stuff but I haven't delved into his more mathematical approaches. I can't speak to his track record, but his critique on risk analysis is very convincing and comes with lots of evidence. A lot of his thought is a distillation of benoit mandelbrot on financial markets. His twitter is too personal for my liking.

text: Also a good read is "The (Mis)behaviour or Markets"

text: I bought the black swan many years ago but could never seem to get past the first couple of chapters. There’s something about his writing style that didn’t sit well with me. He’s obviously a clever chap but he likes to remind you of that often.

text: I actually blocked him on twitter. He might be the genius he clearly considers himself to be but he is also an abrasive manchild and elite tier arsehole IMO. As a consequence I've not read anything of his no matter how good the recommendation. I'm one of those small minded types who struggles to separate the artist from the art. I concede that this means I'm missing out on good content, but if his writing style is in any way similar to his twitter behaviour, then I am happy to take it on the chin.

text: Don't think you'll miss anything significant by not reading it. To me, Black Swan was just trying to make a name for itself by building on Kahneman's Fast & Slow - as have many others. And, I think I remember feeling that the writing style was pretty poor as mentioned earlier.

text:
I've been chatting here with some people and I'm considering starting to use flumine in order to get around some issues I am having with the HTTPS client component that I currently use in my own setup. I've a question about the use of thread pools really. At times I will need to place bets across many distinct strategies in a way that they are all fired within as little as 1 millisecond of eachother. This causes the component I use a few problems the result being that my requests are queued in an opaque manner and I suffer placement latency.

When using a thread pool I'm trying to find out what the lay of the land is. Alternatively, if I write my own thread pool trying to find a best practice implementation based around the betfair API:

1. Does each thread in the pool maintain a HTTPS connection to the server (in the keep-alive sense) at all times so that when called up it is ready to immediately transmit the request, or does it sit idle and go through the whole SSL handshake process every time?
2. Are threads created at the start of the program and persist until it terminates? I am guessing this is the case due to overheads in firing up new threads in an on-demand manner?
3. Within each thread, is a "global" session token shared across the entire application, or does each thread make a separate login and manage its own connection? If the latter, is that frowned upon by betfair (do they have a limit on the number of active sessions each user account can make)?
I am a bit of a dunce with how HTTPS works under the surface and I am trying to get some support for the components I am using but the CS reps are all but accusing me of trying to create something that causes a DOS on a target so I'm getting nowhere (other than getting pissed off with them). When mentioning that I might want to fire off several requests to a server within a single figure millisecond time interval I am being told that my use case is "very unusual" and they are proving to be very unhelpful.

elements.text:
I've been chatting here with some people and I'm considering starting to use flumine in order to get around some issues I am having with the HTTPS client component that I currently use in my own setup. I've a question about the use of thread pools really. At times I will need to place bets across many distinct strategies in a way that they are all fired within as little as 1 millisecond of eachother. This causes the component I use a few problems the result being that my requests are queued in an opaque manner and I suffer placement latency.

When using a thread pool I'm trying to find out what the lay of the land is. Alternatively, if I write my own thread pool trying to find a best practice implementation based around the betfair API:

Does each thread in the pool maintain a HTTPS connection to the server (in the keep-alive sense) at all times so that when called up it is ready to immediately transmit the request, or does it sit idle and go through the whole SSL handshake process every time?
Are threads created at the start of the program and persist until it terminates? I am guessing this is the case due to overheads in firing up new threads in an on-demand manner?

Within each thread, is a "global" session token shared across the entire application, or does each thread make a separate login and manage its own connection? If the latter, is that frowned upon by betfair (do they have a limit on the number of active sessions each user account can make)?

I am a bit of a dunce with how HTTPS works under the surface and I am trying to get some support for the components I am using but the CS reps are all but accusing me of trying to create something that causes a DOS on a target so I'm getting nowhere (other than getting pissed off with them). When mentioning that I might want to fire off several requests to a server within a single figure millisecond time interval I am being told that my use case is "very unusual" and they are proving to be very unhelpful.

text:
Seems a bit drastic migrating your whole project for a bug. Maybe ask here or bdp for help with that?
Have you tested to see if placing bets 1ms to 10ms apart really has the impact you think it does?
With regards to flumine, strategies are run sequentially for each update so depending on what your strategies are doing it’s unlikely you can loop through all them and execute in under 1ms.

In regards to your questions,
1. Maintains a session
2. They are created when needed and recreated of older than 200 seconds
3. Yes
Most of that logic is <https://github.com/betcode-org/flumine/blob/master/flumine/execution/baseexecution.py|here>

attachments.title: <https://github.com/betcode-org/flumine/blob/master/flumine/execution/baseexecution.py | baseexecution.py>

text: It appears that my component is limited to 6 max parallel connections to the server. Last year this cost me a lot of money as I was not using async bet placement. So lets say I had 15 strategies, each wanting to have bets placed (inplay). 6 would get sent straight away, but the remaning 9 would be queued until one of the 6 connections was free. Inplay horses that takes 1 second. My strategies could request more bets to be placed on any price update - so you see how quickly that could escalate. I've changed my stuff significantly since then but I still get the odd excessive lag if things line up in the right (wrong) way. It is a problem that would simply disappear completely with a thread pool I feel

Inplay horses that takes 1 second. My strategies could request more bets to be placed on any price update - so you see how quickly that could escalate. I've changed my stuff significantly since then but I still get the odd excessive lag if things line up in the right (wrong) way. It is a problem that would simply disappear completely with a thread pool I feel

text:
I really don't think this is an area where you want to be relying on a 3rd party that doesn't understand your use case. It does seem strange to me that there isn't more out there regarding low latency HTTPS connection pools but I guess it's too niche/people are too protective of their own implementations. I have my own in C, originally built on top of libcurl but now using my own custom HTTPS client. Whether you need to do that or not depends on whether you really need what that offers you over the flumine implementation which, from a first glance at the code <@UUCD6P13J> shared, looks solid. Not that I would expect anything else!

I highly recommend when pushing requests to a pool like this that there is a check immediately before bet placement between the time the request was generated and the time now and discarding anything greater than a tight threshold. That would have avoided your previous problems but no doubt would not have been possible if using a 3rd party component that you have no internal access to

I have my own in C, originally built on top of libcurl but now using my own custom HTTPS client. Whether you need to do that or not depends on whether you really need what that offers you over the flumine implementation which, from a first glance at the code

shared, looks solid. Not that I would expect anything else!

I highly recommend when pushing requests to a pool like this that there is a check immediately before bet placement between the time the request was generated and the time now and discarding anything greater than a tight threshold. That would have avoided your previous problems but no doubt would not have been possible if using a 3rd party component that you have no internal access to
